results.title: Four colonial painters 1832-1896
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian eye”.
Launceston and the River Tamar (10min): An Australian landscape by John Glover. “The Conciliation” (10min): A “history” painting done in 1840 by Benjamin Duterrau. “Mount William from Mount Dryden” (10min): This landscape reveals Eugene Von Guerard’s Romanticism. “Lake St. Clair” (10min): Work by William Charles Piquenit. Rated: G

results.title: Symbolism and luxury: the new century 1897-1911
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian eye”.
The Spirit of the Plains (10min): Painted in 1897, this is one of Sydney Long’s finest pieces of work. Endormies: A painting by Rupert Bunny. The Mother (9min): Examines the range and quality of artist George Lambert’s best work. The Ferry (8min): This painting is the sunniest and most lyrical of E. Phillips Fox’s paintings.

results.title: Melbourne
results.creator_credit: Douglas White, Eric Thompson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life in Australia”.
This film, directed by Douglas White, opens to the roar of a crowd at the MCG. The camera then sweeps across the city of Melbourne as the soundtrack fades to an easy listening score by composer George Dreyfus (notable for his TV score works like the classic theme from Rush). The film has no commentary, just a skeleton narrative, which is ingeniously used to feature the city of Melbourne. We see a young man wave goodbye to his mum and drive past the commission flats to pick up his girlfriend (Meg from “Prisoner” - the young Elspeth Ballantyne). In the city, people work and shop and the music turns more dramatic as the crowds and traffic grow. In the evening the couple window shop for funky furniture and see “Busybody” at Her Majesty’s, then twist the light fantastic at a bar. Part of the Life in Australia series, produced by The Australian Commonwealth Film Unit.

results.title: Melbourne: the school of the forties 1943-1947
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian eye”.
The Expressionist Eye (13 min) - A look at a period of Australian art that was influenced by European Expressionism. “Victory Girls” (9 min) - A film about Australian artist, Albert Tucker and his work. “Mining Town” (10 min) - an examination of this Arthur Boyd painting. “Stringybark Creek” (10 min) - examines the art of Sidney Nolan. Rated: G
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia

results.title: Contemporary painting 1950-1979
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian eye”.
Features “The Harbour from McMahon’s Point” - Looks at the work of Lloyd Rees. “Epiphany” - A powerful painting by Ian Fairweather. “Self portrait in the Studio” - by Brett Whiteley - “Truck and Trailer Heading into a City” - Examines the work of Jeffrey Smart. “Waterfall Polyptych” - by Fred Williams.

results.title: Perth
results.creator_credit: Henry Lewes, Eric Thompson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life in Australia”.
A pictorial story with minimum commentary on the city of Perth. The daily newspaper is used as the medium to reflect, social, business and sporting activities of the average Australian family living in the city of Perth.

results.title: 'Victory girls', Albert Tucker, 1943
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton, Australian National Gallery and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 20 of Series “The Australian eye”.
An examination of some of the powerful and disturbing paintings of Albert Tucker. Talks of the influence wartime Melbourne had on his work which is reflected in “Victory girls”. Also describes the way in which one particular obsessive image, the crescent shape, found in “Victory girls” emerged to take over the design of a number of his works. Narrated by Albert Tucker.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Muir, Malcolm Otton, Australian National Gallery and Film Australia

results.title: Geraldton
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Eric Thompson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life in Australia”.
Geraldton, Western Australia, is a fast developing town as it is the major supply centre and port of the north of the state. A glimpse of the people, industries, such as building and crayfishing, and social life of Geraldton.
